Fields.DialogueText: Ouch! How does he do it?
What are you trying to figure out? Wait, why are you bleeding?!
Don't worry, Capitano; it's just a minor cut for a Belle. I was trying to do a little experiment.
What kind of experiment?
Saint Januarius' blood, now dried and fossilized, turns to liquid when placed near a holy relic.
Is January named after him?
No, but he is the patron saint of my homeland, Naples.
Interesting. I still don't understand what you were up to.
Well, I was wondering if you could reverse this process and make liquids dry? Since us Bellas Phantasmas are already machines, I thought it might work for me.

Fields.MenuText: I think you might get better results the other way around.
You should be more careful with yourself. Even if it doesn't really injure you, it still scares me.
The saint's miracle might be more a matter of spiritual faith than science.

Fields.DialogueText: You might have a good point; it's best to try to mirror the process before I get into reversing it.
I'm sorry. I'll try to take better care of myself.
And the Bellas are not? We can bring about a new age, Capitano, one that firmly links the myths of the past and present to advancing technology.
I guess I'll put that experiment to the side for now. We have more immediate issues to worry about.
I see what you mean. Perhaps we can test if Morganas bleed.
@BATTLE
Um, Lampo... ?
Yes?
Wah! Watch where you're swinging that thing!
Sorry. I'll try to be more careful.
That's all right. More importantly, why are you hauling a marble pillar down the hallway?
Oh, just a little project. I meant for it to be a surprise.
Lampo...
Okay... I just thought that a full-fledged, Roman-style bath would be interesting to install into the ship.
Oh, really?
Yes, I was just about to begin work. Would you like to watch?

Fields.MenuText: Lampo, isn't this sort of project expensive?
We can't overload you with too many things, or you won't be able to keep up with Morganas in combat.
Well, you are rather clever, so I'll trust that you can make things work.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah... and I do need to save up for some of my other projects. But still, it would be lovely...
Good point. I don't want to lose my fabled speed.
Thanks. I know that I can make everything fit perfectly.
Okay, you can make a bath, just as long as it isn't too over the top.
Thank you, Capitano. Don't worry, it will be great when I complete it.
Ah, those brats are so stubborn! Hang on, I'm going to close in and strike!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Hmmm...
You look really engrossed in that book. What are you reading?
A cookbook.
Ah. Trying to make an Italian meal again?
Maybe, if I can get through this material. I know how to arrange girders and align vents, but  I just cannot get pasta to work!
Does it really matter so much? You're a great mechanic and soldier.
I know, but... since my inventions are failing to do proper service to my country, I have to find something that can truly please them.

Fields.MenuText: Didn't pasta come from China? You can always innovate, you know.
Sometimes the best contributions are only recognized later.
You'll get there, I know it.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. Why chain myself to the past when I can bring Italy's cuisine to the future?
Good point. My current cooking may be unorthodox, but who knows? One day, it may be the height of culinary taste.
Thanks. I think I'm already getting a hang of these techniques.
Well, I'll leave you be for now so you can read in peace.
Actually, I was about done. Want to do something?
*ALARM*
Looks like we'll have to handle some pests, first.
@BATTLE
That wasn't quite what I meant...
Oh no!
Lampo, what's wrong?
My papers...
You mean the designs you were working on? Did you run into another roadblock?
No, worse.
Oh, I see. They fell overboard. We could still try to retrieve them.
No, by now they'll be soggy. Now what do I do?

Fields.MenuText: Well, live and learn. Now you know to be more careful with them.
Don't worry. You have a bright mind, so you can still recover from this.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I need to keep my belongings safer in the future.
Thanks, it has been tough with all these setbacks, though.
I could still dive down and snag the remnants for you, if that helps.
No, it's too late, now. But thanks anyway. Besides, we have company.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Hm-hm-hmmm!
Lampo? Lampo!
Wait, what?! Oh, Captain! What's wrong?
Nothing, but I was wondering why you weren't answering me. No wonder, with those headphones on.
Just listening to opera as I tinker away with things.

Fields.MenuText: Mind if you share the music for a little bit? Call me curious.
Please turn down the music a little – you need to be able to hear things around you as well.
Opera and mechanical work – that's an unusual combination.

Fields.DialogueText: Sure. You can have the left piece, and I'll take the right.
You don't need to worry. I can be in multiple places at once, you know.
Well, I think it is quite a lovely mix.
Hey, could you get everybody to lower down that racket? I'm getting to the good part of the opera.
You'll have to listen to the opera later, Lampo. That "racket" is actually a Morgana.
@BATTLE
Then why didn't you notice me?
... Sorry, can't hear you right now.
I never said it was bad.
What are you working on now?
Oh, hey, Capitano! I was just sprucing up this old car.
Trying to make it into a race car?
Exactly. Mind passing me that wrench, please?
Sure. This car looks a little small for you, though.
I know. This is one that I want you to test drive.
Oh? I know I agreed to be your driver, but...
I still need to work out the best method. But it takes a lot of training to become a driver, so we can't afford to wait.

Fields.MenuText: We still need to find a safe spot to practice.
Maybe I should read up on how to handle race cars first.
Then, let's get started!

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I could always build a race track through the ship.
That's a good thought, but you also need to experience it for yourself.
That's the spirit! Just let me finish this up.
All right, Capitano! Just take a seat inside and we'll see how it feels!
It's a little tight in here, but i could get used to it. What's that noise I'm hearing outside? The car's kind of muffling it.
Oh, just a Morgana closing in.
Oh, I see – what?!
We'll need to do the training later. I need to get into action fast!
@BATTLE
"'O soave fanciulla, o dolce viso..."
Singing some opera?
Yes, from La Boheme by Puccini.
It sounds lovely. What is it about?
A love story. I was actually singing the man's part – Rodolfo's. Next comes his lover, Mimi. "Ah, tu sol comandi, amor!"
Amazing. I'm impressed that you can play both parts.
Well, it's not easy, but I don't have much of a choice without a duet partner.

Fields.MenuText: For the record, I think you captured the emotions of both characters fluidly.
Do you think I could do the other half for you?
Maybe we should host an opera some time?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. One thing I love about opera is trying to convey the emotions of people. If I can understand their feelings, I can link their dreams to mine.
If you're interested, I could give you a few lessons.
Really? If it is not too much trouble, I would love to do that.
Well, I'll leave you to the singing for now. I need to check on the rest of the ship.
All right. "O buon Marcello, aiutoooooh!"
You might want to work on that last bit some more.
Oh, that was for a different reason. We have another Morgana fleet approaching!
One of these days, those monsters will sing their final swan song.
@BATTLE
No problem. It would be a lot of fun.
Wait... that's it!
Lampo, now's not the time to make sudden interjections like that!
There's no rest for inspiration, Capitano.
Even two minutes before a battle?
Nope. But anyway, I think I just found a solution to our troubles.
Which troubles in particular? There's more than I can list on my fingers.
Sorry! I meant about the difficulty that ships have in navigating cities.
You have certainly complained enough about racing ambitions. Did you find a solution to that?
Not exactly. It won't let you drive me through the streets of Rome, but there's another way to do so. We just need a city large enough.
But what sort of city exists that... wait, don't tell me...
Precisely. Aetherial Babylon is going to be in the sky, so we can make it as large as we wish.
That's one way to go about it, I guess.
I won't even have to refit myself for land duty. I can't wait to host – and be part of – a race there!

Fields.MenuText: Don't count your chickens before they hatch.
Great! Then we really will be able to race and win together.
We'll have to find a way for the ships to get up to the city to begin with.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. Now the serious testing begins.
Right! We'll show them all just how unstoppable we are.
Don't worry; I'm already working on that issue.
Anyway, it's great that your ideas are coming together. I can't wait to see the city you make.
Between my brains and my swiftness, we'll get there in no time.
Right now, though, let's use your speed for something else. Those Morganas are trying to make a break for it!
@BATTLE
Water, water! Where's some water?
Lampo, what's with the smoke – is that cup of wine... on fire?
Don't just stand there! I need water, yesterday!
All right, here! Okay, now that this little catastrophe is dealt with, would you please mind explaining what you were up to?
I was trying a new recipe, but things didn't quite work out the way I wanted them to.
I can see that. But I'm still a little surprised – you generally do pretty well with wines, unlike pasta.
I was trying to mix a new, unique brew. Here – a little of it didn't get caught in the blaze.
Is that... oil?
Yes. I was trying to find a reasonable balance between the oil and alcohol, so that it would be appealing to both Belles and humans alike. I just forget how flammable it can be.

Fields.MenuText: You certainly have an innovative mind.
Try to be a little more careful next time, we don't want any accidents.
Maybe it would work better if you found some sort of ingredient that simulated the taste of oil.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. I always think that it is good to look outside the box – even if the box is what's keeping you afloat.
Okay. I'll try to experiment in more controlled environments.
That's an interesting approach. I'll have to look into that.
So, want a sip of that oil-wine? I think it tasted rather fine.
I'd like to not accidentally catch on fire. It's bad enough when the Morganas try to light us up.
And speak of the Devil... here they are again.
@BATTLE
Hey, Lampo?
Yes, Capitano? I'm just finishing up this painting.
You are? I was bringing over your painting supplies because I thought you forgot them.
Thanks, but it turns out I didn't need them. Tada!
Impressive. I like the texture and shading you pulled off. But where did you find the paints?
I decided to take a different approach this time. You see, I had been working on some repairs when my canvas got coated with water and grime; but then I had an idea.
I see. You used the muck and other stuff for the coloring. That's a pretty unique approach.
Thanks. It's a little unorthodox, but I think that this can give a whole new dimension to art.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose it does give a new definition to "oil" and "watercolors."
I'm not sure how this will stay preserved, though.
Does it really count as art?

Fields.DialogueText: Tee-hee! You're right!
I'm sure I'll figure out a solution in time.
Of course! This is not some slap job you can do effortlessly. It takes careful attention to get everything just right.
Well, I must say, you did a great job with this.
Thank you. Maybe we could hang it in the hallway?
Sure, as long as it doesn't leave a stain. It will look really nice there.
It just goes to show that one person's junk is another's treasure.
*ALARM*
Well, the real trash just arrived. Time to incinerate it.
@BATTLE
It's finished!
What's finished? Did you finally complete your city design?
No, but it's coming along smoothly. I mean my spaghetti!
Oh, you managed to cook some without burning the batch. That's great!
I know! Now I am a true lady of Italy, both an innovator and a great cook. So come on, sit down.
You want me to taste the spaghetti?
Well, I'd like to try some, too. But food is for sharing – let it not be said that I lack my nation's virtue of hospitality.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you. Someday, I want to make something for you as well.
It tastes wonderful.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh? I can share some recipes with you if you would like.
Thank you, that means a lot to me.
That was a delicious meal.
Thanks. For a while, I wasn't sure I would get things right.
But see? You kept at it and worked things out. I'm sure the city idea will work out in the end, too.
I know it will. Now then, we just need to pick up and...
*BOOM*
Those Morganas certainly make a mess wherever they go.
@BATTLE
*sigh*
Lampo, what's wrong? You're crying!
I... got a message from headquarters.
Back in Italy? What's wrong? Did someone close to you get hurt?
No, nothing like that. It was all about me and my silly ideas.
Your ideas are not silly, Lampo. They're very inspiring.
His Excellency apparently disagrees. I have been told to refine my designs and focus on "militarily expedient objectives."
Well, they didn't cancel your projects.
Yes, but what's the point, now? It's just... with all the restrictions, I don't know if I want to pursue the idea anymore.
Do you need their yes or no to act on your dream, though? You could still continue your project, even without their backing.
What? But... this is my duty, for the good of the nation and the future. If I have to set aside my own dreams for a greater goal, I must comply.

Fields.MenuText: I admire your strong will and determination, Lampo. That's why it makes me so sad that you let them bully you.
Your dreams matter, Lampo. They deserve just as much a chance as anyone else, and they can become real – I know it.
In the end, you'll need to decide what matters more to you. It's a tough choice, I know, but at one point or another you will have to choose.

Fields.DialogueText: They're not bullies! They're heroes for the world and its future. They're... I don't know.
Yes, dreams are important. I just... don't want to make people waste time on mine when there are others to be fulfilled as well.
You're right. We're all going to have to make tough choices, aren't we? Either now... or when the war – or this war, at least – ends.
You have given me a lot of things to consider, Capitano. I don't know if I can do it alone, though.
You won't be alone. Lampo... I may not know the most about how to make your idea happen, but I want to work on it with you until the very end.
You will? Capitano, thank you!
*ALARM*
We'll have to set aside the planning for later. Right now, let's teach these Morganas not to mess with us.
Yes! Working together, nothing can stop us!
@BATTLE
It only becomes a waste if you give up on it.
Now that we're finished with those Morganas, should we get to work on the drafts for your city?
Okay. Now to start brainstorming. If you'll excuse me...
Lampo, I said I would help you, right?
I know, and I'm grateful for that. It's just... I don't know exactly what you can do to help with it.
Lampo, I really want to help. If there is any way I can make your wish come true, I'll do it.
I know that. But I've done all of it on my own until now, and I don't know what you could start with. It's all very complicated.

Fields.MenuText: What if you taught me some of the skills? That way I could help you more efficiently.
Since we're partners in this, I can cover the areas that you have the most difficulty with.
I don't know what to do exactly, but I still want to help.

Fields.DialogueText: That could work. It would take a lot of dedication to learn, though.
You're right. We can each bring out the best parts of each other in this project.
Thanks. I'll find a way for us to work together, I promise.
Wait, I think I have an idea. For now, do you think you could give your thoughts on my project?
I'm not sure I will know all the technical details necessary for that sort of analysis.
That doesn't matter. Just getting the opinion of someone else will be integral in moving forward. From there we can expand your role!
Perfect. Then let's get to work...
Anything for you.
*ALARM*
...on defeating the Morganas that is.
@BATTLE
Lampo! Are you okay?
I'm hanging in there, Captain. That hit gave me a limp, but I'm still ready to fight.
Are you sure? You've slowed down a bit.
That's because the engines took some damage. I had to slow down to do some repairs.
But the Morganas are starting to get away. We have to catch them!
I know that! You know I'd rather be cruising along top-speed right now. But I have to be careful, or someone might get hurt.

Fields.MenuText: I've got your back. Tell me what I can do to help.
Don't worry. Get the job done right, and we'll catch up with it.
Calm down and think things through. It's going to be okay.

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks. Help me with this pipe over here, and we'll be good.
You're right. That Morgana may think itself the hare, but its shell will be exposed once I catch it!
Good point. I need to make sure things are done just right.
There! All done! Now, hold on!
I started grabbing onto a rail as soon as you announced you were finished. You certainly love high-speed chases.
I sure do! It's even more fun when I close in on the target and there's nowhere to run!
@BATTLE
Phew! That was a good battle.
Certainly, we came out on top!
Yes, but you had better check for leaks. We don't want to end up at the bottom of the sea.
Actually, that would be an interesting idea?
To sink the boat?
Not that. But if you could safely travel deep underwater without limitations, just think of all the possibilities.

Fields.MenuText: The features you'd need for underwater travel would probably be different from those for sailing on the surface.
You would need to get all the details perfect for it to work. One little mistake, and there's no coming back.
It would be quite amazing.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, but in this modern age we can find ways to surpass the barriers that once blocked us.
I know, but I can't let the idea go.
Exactly. Perhaps the dreams of Verne can be fulfilled soon.
Well, you have an ingenious mind, so I have no doubt that you can figure it out.
Thanks. The chaotic, majestic seas are the heart of this world, you know? And with enough effort, we can bring those mysterious secrets to the surface.
Just as long as the Morganas don't get the same idea. We have enough trouble already without them truly becoming sea monsters.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Good news and bad news about Aetherial Babylon.
Let's start with the bad news first and get it over with.
It won't make sense without the good news.
Isn't that the way it always goes? All right, let's hear the good news.
The good news is that I am about finished with the design phase. From here on, we can begin to move toward modeling and actual, physical tests.
That's great! So... what's the bad news?
In a way, that is the bad news. We have to move on to the construction phase, and those sorts of things require resources – and finances.
I see. And now that your superiors have stopped funding your operation, we don't have anything.
I know, and I cannot see anyway past these straits. Maybe I should just sing and forget my troubles for a while.
Sing... Hey, that's it! Lampo, what if we hosted an opera performance? Then we might have enough money to continue the project.
I... don't know. I enjoy singing in my free time, Capitano, but I'm more of a mechanic and a fighter than an actress.

Fields.MenuText: Even if it doesn't work out, it will still be fun to do, right?
You won't be alone up there, Lampo. We'll succeed together.
You have to believe in yourself. You can do it.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I need to focus not so much on the outcome, but the dream itself. It's that sort of passion that got me to start the project.
Thank you. I don't know where I would be without you.
You're absolutely right. What am I doing, contemplating what ifs? I need to charge forward and make those dreams into reality!
Okay then. This will be great. I can help with the script, the stage, everything.
And I will be there to lend my assistance as well. See? There's really no bad news to worry about.
Actually there is...
@BATTLE
Same here...
*ALARM*
Come on in, Capitano! The water is just right!
Okay, here I go! You did a great job with the bath.
I just hope that you didn't spend too much of our resources fancying the place up. We still have your big project, too.
Don't worry, remember my sludge painting? You can find lots of ways to utilize limited resources.
I can see that. I'm amazed that you got all those statues made. What are they supposed to be of? Some famous Italian monuments?
In a fashion. I based it off the Trevi Fountain.
You did? But where's the fount – oh, is this why I've seen coins at the bottom here?
It's my little plan, for good luck and for funding. When you exit the bath, you can throw three coins behind you.
What do they do?
First coin, you wish to return to the bath. The second coin, you wish to return one day to your homeland. And the third coin... is for your dreams to come true.

Fields.MenuText: Well then, let's make some wishes. So that we may return to our homelands, and see them together.
So as long as we keep wishing for another bath, you are bound to live one day more, forever.
We don't need to make a wish when we already know that we're going to succeed.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. Together, we will see the world, and find our homes again, whether here, on land, or in the sky.
Yes, let's keep that dream alive for as long as we can.
That's right. Let's just wish for more spaghetti?
All right! One, two, three!
There! It's done.
Not done yet. Best to work to fulfill our wishes than just wait.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
All right, Capitano! It's time to practice our singing.
Lampo, we're about to battle! Can't this wait until we're safe?
You should never put things off, or else you might never end up doing them.
We can sing tomorrow!
An opera singer should practice her notes every day without rest. We need to get everything perfect for our performance!

Fields.MenuText: It's kind of loud right now.
We need to win the battle first and foremost.
All right, then. After you.

Fields.DialogueText: That is no trouble. There is always some background music to deal with when singing, so best to get used to it.
But this will help with the battle! Nothing like music to boost the morale of the sailors. Our art and passion sets us above those monsters' wiles.
Great. "Addio, addio!"
Oh, "Parmi veder le lagrime!"
That's the spirit, Capitano. You're doing great!
Thanks. But we need to make sure we get out of here alive before we can sing in peace.
@BATTLE
That was a tough battle, huh?
... Yeah.
Lampo, are you okay? You look a little shaken since that last foray.
Oh, it's nothing, really.
Lampo, please. I want to help.
Those bombs just sort of frightened me. Then I saw some birds overhead, and I froze up.
What do you mean?
You see, a fortune teller once warned me that my death would come from above. Since then, threats from the sky terrify me.
Is that why you want to fly so badly? Because you feel so threatened?
Yes. That way, I won't feel so vulnerable anymore.

Fields.MenuText: The fortune teller was probably a quack. If it turns out to be true, you can sue her for revenge.
Together, we'll reach the skies and give new hope to everyone. Because if we do that, nothing can make us fall.
Sometimes, you have to just stop worrying and enjoy life.

Fields.DialogueText: Come back as a ghost, you mean? I wonder if that's what the Morganas are.
My thoughts exactly. This world has too many dangers looming over everyone's heads. It's about time that we shed some new light and fly toward the sun.
Good point. We should value the preciousness of our time together, no matter what comes next.
Just know that I'm always here for you.
Thanks. With you at my side, those Morganas don't scare me one bit.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Lampo, how are the repairs coming along?
They're going to take a little longer. I'm kind of in a sticky situation right now.
What do you – what is all this gunk?!
Pizza?
Pizza. What is pizza doing in here? I told you to be careful about snacking on the job.
I wasn't having it as a snack. I was cooking it up, actually.
Here, of all places?
Well, I was in the mood for a good, old-fashioned stove pizza, but we didn't have quite the right equipment in the oven. So, I calculated that the heat by the boilers would be perfect.
Did your calculations factor in the mess that might happen?
No, that was an oversight, I admit.

Fields.MenuText: I guess we'll have to make sure the food doesn't go to waste. Time to eat.
Please try to be more careful the next time.
I can always install the right kind of oven if you let me know.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. It's pretty well done, I must say. The coal I used acts as a nice seasoning!
I will. You can't gum up gears like this.
Thanks.
Don't worry, it's not as bad as it looks. Things can still run smoothly for the most part.
*ALARM*
Good. The Morganas don't accept handicaps when they come to play.
@BATTLE
One more time...
What's up, Lampo?
Whoa!
Are you okay? You took quite the fall.
I'm fine! I was just trying to get the hang of piloting a gondola.
I thought you were already an expert at that?
My port of call was not Venice, so I only have second-hand experience. But I want to really master it.
Well, keep at it. I'm sure you'll get the hang of it.
Thank you. Do you have any suggestions on how I should be doing it?

Fields.MenuText: Try whistling a tune while you paddle.
Keep your balance at all costs.
Try to practice keeping a steady rhythm with the oar.

Fields.DialogueText: That would help keep my spirits up. Not to mention that singing is a key part of the entertainment for gondola tours.
Yes, the most important part to consider in any structure is its support foundations.
Good idea. I can get a better understanding of the fluid dynamics.
Thank you for the advice, Capitano.
No need to thank me. I haven't used a gondola in my life.
You should probably beach the gondola for now, it looks like the waves are going to get rough.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All right, Lampo. Ready to perform our duet?
... Okay. Um, actually, I need to fix something real quick.
That's what you said the last time we were about to start. What's wrong?
It's just... I feel kind of nervous.
Is this because I suggested we practice in front of a sample audience?
... Yes.
Lampo, you're the one with the most experience in opera. You should be the person with the least stage fright.
I know! But... I don't want to upset anyone by doing a bad job.

Fields.MenuText: If we mess up, we can share the blame, and, split up like that, the problem won't be much trouble at all.
Just take a deep breath and get into the song before you can hesitate, and then we can keep rolling forward.
We'll get through this together. You're not alone on the stage.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha ha! That's an interesting way to look at it. Thanks. I forgot my fears while laughing.
You're right. The toughest part is always the first step.
Thank you, for being here. Let's do this!
Ready?
Yes.
Then here we go! "Nessun dorma... "
Hold up.
Lampo, there's nothing to be afraid of.
It's not that – a Morgana has come to crash the opera.
Oh, of course...
@BATTLE
Well, the Morganas have certainly assembled a force this time.
Tell me about it. I don't like the looks of this.
Oh, cheer up. These kinds of battles only make us stronger in the end.
If we survive...
Odysseus survived, and so did Aeneas. Compared to those ordeals, this is easy!
I don't think the Greeks and Romans had to worry about things on the level of Morganas.
That just makes things more exciting, doesn't it? Anyway, I'm ready when you are, awaiting your orders.

Fields.MenuText: Weave through the formation and strike at the weak points.
Flank the fleet and hit them from the side.
Wait for them to come closer, and then swoop in.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh. You certainly have me pegged, Captain. Moving like a torpedo yet knowing the structural weaknesses like an engineer – that's me, all right.
Okay, then. Hang on!
All right. But once it's time, I'm speeding into the fray.
Get ready, Lampo. It's almost time.
I'm ready whenever.
Now! Let's go!
@BATTLE
"To His Excellency, I have been thinking... " No, that won't work! "As we proudly march forward to the future of our nation and the world, I feel... "
What are you working on? A soliloquy for an opera?
No, just trying to write a letter.
To who?
... To the Duce, and to Italy.
... Wait. I thought they stopped supporting the project.
They did. But... now that it is finished, I wanted to show it to them one more time.
Even after everything they've said?
... Yes. Just one more chance for them to approve.

Fields.MenuText: Lampo, even if they accept it, does that make all of their past bullying worth it?
You said that your dream is for a better world. What if they don't want to share?
I don't want you to have to beg for recognition, Lampo. Not when I see you for the wonderful genius you are.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know.
It is the destiny of Italy to bring light to the world.
And maybe now they will finally see just how smart and determined I am.
I just feel like you are throwing away all your progress by going back to those bullies.
Who says I am?
What do you mean?
Well, my note to them will just happen to be distributed all across the country. Then all of Italy – and the world – will know.
That's brilliant, Lampo.
I don't know what they will say, but no matter what, I will stand true to myself and my duties to bringing about a great future for all.
It's that kind of determination that makes you so unique. Now let's show it to those Morganas.
@BATTLE
Hey, Capitano, my model for the city is finished. Want to see it?
Sure. You don't have to sound nervous, though. It's going to be fine.
You're right. I just have to have courage...
What?
Nothing. Here it is!
This is incredible, Lampo! It's bigger than me!
Capitano, we did this together, as a team.
You're right. We make a great pair.
We still have a ways to go with Aetherial Babylon, though. Just like our own journey...
Lampo? What do you mean?
You have been a great help to me with this project and with my other endeavors. You're... you're more than just a good friend.
Lampo...
... Would you be interested in a new project, maybe? One that would require dating...
Truthfully... back then, my third wish was for this moment.
Oh, Capitano!
*BOOM*
Oh, for the love of- I'll meet you on the bridge!
It's not the enemy.
Pardon?
It's not the enemy. There's a test of coastal defenses. We're just... closer than we intended to be.
But we're safe? You're sure?
Si. I'm distracted, but not *that* distracted.

Fields.MenuText: I never doubted you.
Funny how there's always something blowing up just when things are getting interesting, huh?
So maybe I need to work harder to distract you.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh? ...Oh!
"Getting interesting," you say?
I'm very glad to hear it.
Hm. Let's see if we can find the proper way to celebrate the city of the future, shall we?
